paragraphs.text: The problem with globes is that these don’t really make it easy to show border changes. There’s a globe that I had as a child (and is still in the basement at my father’s house). It has the former USSR. That globe is now pretty much useless unless you’re teaching the Cold War era to kids.
paragraphs.name: 591b

paragraphs.text: Look at the relative size of Great Britain, for instance, to the rest of the world. If the implicit message here is that size matters in world affairs then how do you explain to students the fact that they ruled the world for a few centuries? Or that the Iberian peninsula contains two nations that conquered South America? How does that help with “decolonizing the curriculum”?
paragraphs.name: 97d3

paragraphs.text: Why is there so much ignorance about what is obviously the most ‘accurate’ and so obviously best projection? That is Buckminster Fuller’s Dymaxion projection. But also the most interesting projection (in that it makes no pretence about our living in a Flat Earth Society, but makes us think about the globe — eg understand why flying in a straight line…

paragraphs.text: Another interesting thing teachers could do would be to give the students only certain bands of latitude. I was astonished to realize that the northernmost point in Japan is only at the latitude of Oregon, and that Paris is at the same latitude as the US-Canadian border.

paragraphs.text: As a social studies teacher, I couldn’t agree more. I would make one alteration, however: lessons involving maps should show multiple maps showing multiple perspectives including geography, topography, languages, industries, climate, borders (real and imagined and historical) to name a few. Never should one map be presented, but multiple to represent multiple realities and histories.
paragraphs.name: 21d5

paragraphs.text: Physical maps have the same problem of becoming outdated. I just assumed schools would keep them up-to-date. The only medium easily updateable is digital (Google Earth, etc.), which can be viewed in either 2D or 3D formats.
